G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20 (to the extent applicable), G.L. c. 215, § 6, and the Massachusetts Child Custody Jurisdiction provisions of G.L. c. 209B, because the children reside in Massachusetts and have done so for more than six months prior to the filing of this Complaint, and Middlesex Probate and Family Court issued the existing custody judgment.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20 (to the extent a.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20 (to the extent applicable), G.L. c. 215, § 6, and the Massachusetts Child Custody Jurisdiction provisions of G.L. c. 209B, because the children reside in Massachusetts and have done so for more than six months prior to the filing of this Complaint, and Middlesex Probate and Family Court issued the existing custody judgment.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20 (to the extent applicable), G.L. c. 215, § 6, and the Massachusetts Child Custody Jurisdiction provisions of G.L. c. 209B, because the children reside in Massachusetts and have done so for more than six months prior to the filing of this Complaint, and Middlesex Probate and Family Court issued the existing custody judgment.

G.L. c. 209B.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20 (to the extent applicable), G.L. c. 215, § 6, and the Massachusetts Child Custody Jurisdiction provisions of G.L. c. 209B, because the children reside in Massachusetts and have done so for more than six months prior to the filing of this Complaint, and Middlesex Probate and Family Court issued the existing custody judgment.

G.L. c. 265, \u00a7 13A.proposition: Upon information and belief, the Paramour has a criminal record in Massachusetts, including at least one conviction or charge for assault and battery, in violation of G.L. c. 265, § 13A, and has previously been the subject of an abuse prevention order pursuant to G.L. c. 209A obtained by a prior intimate partner.

G.L. c. 209A.proposition: Upon information and belief, the Paramour has a criminal record in Massachusetts, including at least one conviction or charge for assault and battery, in violation of G.L. c. 265, § 13A, and has previously been the subject of an abuse prevention order pursuant to G.L. c. 209A obtained by a prior intimate partner.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a custody or parenting-time judgment may be modified when (1) there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior judgment, and (2) modification is necessary to serve the best interests of the child. See G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998).

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a custody or parenting-time judgment may be modified when (1) there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior judgment, and (2) modification is necessary to serve the best interests of the child. See G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998).
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: This opinion concerns an initial custody determination and the need for explicit findings regarding domestic violence and its effect on the child. It does not discuss standards for post‑judgment modification of custody or parenting time, nor does it articulate the “material and substantial change in circumstances” plus “best interests” test for modification under G.L. c. 208, § 28 or G.L. c. 209C, § 20. The case is therefore not authority for the specific modification standard stated in the proposition.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: Domestic violence is an issue too fundamental and frequently recurring to be dealt with only by implication. The very frequency of domestic violence in disputes about child custody may have the effect of inuring courts to it and thus minimizing its significance. Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.

Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a custody or parenting-time judgment may be modified when (1) there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior judgment, and (2) modification is necessary to serve the best interests of the child. See G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998).
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely articulates the modification standard for custody in Massachusetts, stating that a Probate and Family Court judge may modify an earlier custody judgment upon finding both a material and substantial change in circumstances and that the modification is necessary in the best interests of the child. The court quotes G.L. c. 208, § 28, and applies that two-part test to vacate the custody modification for lack of adequate best-interests findings, directly supporting the proposition cited.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, provides that a Probate and Family Court judge may modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody of a minor child on finding ‘that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the child[].’”

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: The best interests of the child are the paramount consideration in any custody or parenting-time determination or modification. See G.L. c. 208, § 31; Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225–26 (1998); Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840–41 (2003).

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u20.proposition: The best interests of the child are the paramount consideration in any custody or parenting-time determination or modification. See G.L. c. 208, § 31; Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225–26 (1998); Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840–41 (2003).
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u20.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely frames the dispositive issue in terms of the child’s best interests once parental unfitness is found, citing G.L. c. 210, § 3(c), and treats that best-interests inquiry as the controlling standard in deciding between competing custodial/adoptive placements. Although the case involves adoption/custody under c. 210 and c. 119 rather than c. 208, its reasoning confirms that the best interests of the child are the paramount consideration in determining custody or placement, aligning with the proposition for which it is cited.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u20.relevant_excerpt: “Once the judge concluded that parental unfitness was established, he correctly determined that the central question was whether it was in Hugo’s best interests to remain with his foster mother or to be transferred to the care and custody of his aunt. G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c). The ‘best interests of a child’ is a question that presents the trial judge ‘with a classic example of a discretionary decision.’… Presented with more than one potential adoption placement, the judge’s task is to determine which plan will serve the best interests of the child…”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u201.proposition: The best interests of the child are the paramount consideration in any custody or parenting-time determination or modification. See G.L. c. 208, § 31; Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225–26 (1998); Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840–41 (2003).
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly discusses the historical development and continued application of the ‘best interests of the child’ standard as the guiding principle in custody matters and reiterates that custody determinations are made based on that standard. It cites earlier Massachusetts cases such as Yannas and Blixt to affirm that the best interests of the child is the controlling, paramount consideration in custody and visitation decisions. Thus, it squarely supports the proposition that best interests are paramount in custody/parenting-time determinations or modifications.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u201.relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… The ‘best interests’ standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865… It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt… (best interests standard ‘has long been used in Massachusetts to decide issues of custody and visitation’); Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas… (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’).”

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31A.proposition: The Court is required to consider the effect of domestic violence, abuse, or a pattern of coercive or controlling behavior on the best interests of the child and on custody and parenting-time decisions. See G.L. c. 208, § 31A; G.L. c. 209C, § 10; Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. at 595–96; Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 845–46.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 10.proposition: The Court is required to consider the effect of domestic violence, abuse, or a pattern of coercive or controlling behavior on the best interests of the child and on custody and parenting-time decisions. See G.L. c. 208, § 31A; G.L. c. 209C, § 10; Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. at 595–96; Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 845–46.

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. at 595\u201.proposition: The Court is required to consider the effect of domestic violence, abuse, or a pattern of coercive or controlling behavior on the best interests of the child and on custody and parenting-time decisions. See G.L. c. 208, § 31A; G.L. c. 209C, § 10; Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. at 595–96; Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 845–46.

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 845\u20134.proposition: The Court is required to consider the effect of domestic violence, abuse, or a pattern of coercive or controlling behavior on the best interests of the child and on custody and parenting-time decisions. See G.L. c. 208, § 31A; G.L. c. 209C, § 10; Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. at 595–96; Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 845–46.

Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649, 658\u2013.proposition: While a parent’s choice of romantic partner is generally a matter of personal autonomy, Massachusetts courts may impose reasonable conditions on parenting time when the presence or conduct of a third party poses a risk to a child’s safety or welfare. See Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649, 658–59 (2002) (recognizing broad equitable powers of Probate and Family Court to fashion orders protecting children’s welfare); Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232, 234–35 (1981) (upholding court’s power to impose restrictions in the child’s best interests).
Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649, 658\u2013.support_reasoning: Blixt concerns the constitutionality and construction of the Massachusetts grandparent visitation statute and the Probate and Family Court’s equitable authority to protect children from harm in that context. It does not address parenting time conditions relating to a parent’s romantic partner or any third-party cohabitant in the sense used in the proposition (e.g., limiting a partner’s presence during visits). While it recognizes the court’s broad power to protect children’s welfare in visitation matters, relying on Blixt for the specific rule about regulating parenting time based on a romantic partner’s presence is too indirect and not supported by the facts or holding of the case.
Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649, 658\u2013.relevant_excerpt: “It cannot be disputed that the State has a compelling interest to protect children from actual or potential harm. … This interest is expressed in a variety of statutes and proceedings, ranging from the complete severance of parental rights on a judge’s finding of parental unfitness, to the limitation of parental choices in the areas, for example, of education, health care, and safety. … [T]he statute satisfies strict scrutiny because our construction narrowly tailors it to further the compelling State interest in protecting the welfare of a child….”

Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232, 234\u20.proposition: While a parent’s choice of romantic partner is generally a matter of personal autonomy, Massachusetts courts may impose reasonable conditions on parenting time when the presence or conduct of a third party poses a risk to a child’s safety or welfare. See Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649, 658–59 (2002) (recognizing broad equitable powers of Probate and Family Court to fashion orders protecting children’s welfare); Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232, 234–35 (1981) (upholding court’s power to impose restrictions in the child’s best interests).
Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232, 234\u20.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly recognizes that in serving the child’s best interests, a court may limit a parent’s liberties (including religious/associational aspects of visitation) when there is demonstrated harm or risk to the child’s welfare. Although the court reverses the restriction here because the evidentiary showing of harm was insufficient, it clearly affirms the Probate Court’s power, in principle, to impose such conditions on parenting time when supported by proof. Thus, it supports the proposition about the court’s authority to impose reasonable conditions to protect a child’s safety or welfare, even though the specific restriction in this case was not upheld on the record presented.
Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232, 234\u20.relevant_excerpt: But the “best interests” of the child are to be promoted, and when the parents are at odds, the attainment of that purpose may involve some limitation of the liberties of one or other of the parents. … [H]arm to the child from conflicting religious instructions or practices, which would justify such a limitation, should not be simply assumed or surmised; it must be demonstrated in detail. … The few cases which, though faithful to the accepted legal pattern earlier described, limit visitation because of religious differences, have relied on firmer proof.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28, 31.proposition: The Probate and Family Court has broad equitable authority to enter orders necessary to protect children and to craft parenting-time conditions tailored to the family’s circumstances, including supervised parenting time, requirements regarding the presence of third parties, and conditions to ensure safety. See G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31; G.L. c. 215, § 6; Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985); Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 842–43.

Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.proposition: The Probate and Family Court has broad equitable authority to enter orders necessary to protect children and to craft parenting-time conditions tailored to the family’s circumstances, including supervised parenting time, requirements regarding the presence of third parties, and conditions to ensure safety. See G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31; G.L. c. 215, § 6; Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985); Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 842–43.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.support_reasoning: Yannas concerns standards for removal of children from the Commonwealth and general custody determinations, not the scope of the Probate and Family Court’s broad equitable authority to craft specific parenting‑time conditions such as supervised contact, presence of third parties, or safety‑related terms. The opinion analyzes G.L. c. 208, §§ 30–31 regarding custody and removal, and touches only incidentally on visitation scheduling, without articulating any principle about broad equitable remedial powers under G.L. c. 215, § 6 or tailored parenting‑time conditions. It therefore does not meaningfully support the specific proposition for which it is cited.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “Cases involving removal of a child from the jurisdiction present difficult choices. Unless one is to apply a fixed but arbitrary rule, the issue can be resolved only on a case by case basis. The effect on the child of any removal is most important. An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change … and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 842\u20134.proposition: The Probate and Family Court has broad equitable authority to enter orders necessary to protect children and to craft parenting-time conditions tailored to the family’s circumstances, including supervised parenting time, requirements regarding the presence of third parties, and conditions to ensure safety. See G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31; G.L. c. 215, § 6; Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985); Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 842–43.

Adoption of Simone, 427 Mass. 34, 43\u20.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that exposure to domestic violence or to a violent household—whether or not the child is the direct victim—is highly relevant to the best-interests analysis and may warrant modification of custody or parenting-time orders. See G.L. c. 208, § 31A; Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. at 595–96; Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. at 225–26; Adoption of Simone, 427 Mass. 34, 43–44 (1998).
Adoption of Simone, 427 Mass. 34, 43\u20.support_reasoning: The Simone opinion excerpt deals with jurisdiction, use of prior care-and-protection findings, due process, and appellate procedure in a petition to dispense with consent to adoption. It does not discuss domestic violence, exposure to a violent household, or how such exposure factors into a best-interests analysis or custody/parenting-time modification. Because the case does not address that subject at all, it does not provide authority for the specific domestic-violence-related proposition for which it is cited.
Adoption of Simone, 427 Mass. 34, 43\u20.relevant_excerpt: In the present case, the findings in the care and protection proceeding were indeed relevant in determining Simone’s best interests. See G. L. c. 210, § 3 (b), (c). Furthermore, the same judge presided over both proceedings and found no reason to revise his earlier findings. Rather, he had reason to take an even more unfavorable view of the biological parents’ abilities to parent Simone: the judge found that, since moving to Puerto Rico, the biological parents took no step to contact Simone or the department.

Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610, 61.proposition: In determining whether a modification is in the children’s best interests, the Court may consider the emotional stability of the home, the presence of conflict, and the impact of the parent’s associates or household members on the children’s safety and well‑being. See Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610, 618–19 (1986); Care & Protection of Lillith, 61 Mass. App. Ct. 132, 141–42 (2004).
Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610, 61.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly grounds the best‑interests/unfitness analysis in the emotional stability of the home, the presence of conflict and violence, and the likely impact of that environment on the children’s safety and emotional well‑being. The court relies on findings that the child needs “an emotionally stable home environment,” notes the parents’ “proclivity for violence,” and approves the judge’s conclusion that returning the children would expose them to emotional and physical harm, thus supporting consideration of these factors in modification/best‑interests determinations.
Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610, 61.relevant_excerpt: “The judge adopted the opinion of the psychologist at Children’s Hospital Medical Center, that the son needed an emotionally stable home environment unavailable to him in the home of his parents… Social workers and other professionals providing therapy and other services to the family were virtually unanimous in stating that the parents were not presently fit to care for the children and that the children would be in danger of being subjected to emotional and physical harm if returned to the custody of their parents immediately. The judge could properly have concluded that committing the children to the custody of the department would be in their best interest.”

Care & Protection of Lillith, 61 Mass. A.raw_text: Care & Protection of Lillith, 61 Mass. App. Ct. 132, 141–42 (2004)
Care & Protection of Lillith, 61 Mass. A.proposition: In determining whether a modification is in the children’s best interests, the Court may consider the emotional stability of the home, the presence of conflict, and the impact of the parent’s associates or household members on the children’s safety and well‑being. See Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610, 618–19 (1986); Care & Protection of Lillith, 61 Mass. App. Ct. 132, 141–42 (2004).
Care & Protection of Lillith, 61 Mass. A.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses factors relevant to parental fitness and best interests in a care and protection/custody context, but it does not articulate or apply a rule that, in modification proceedings, courts may consider emotional stability of the home, presence of conflict, or the impact of associates/household members on the children’s safety and well‑being. Its analysis focuses on the mother’s mental health, drug use, instability, and the father’s domestic violence history, without framing a broader best‑interests standard of the type stated in the proposition. Thus, it does not serve as direct authority for that specific proposition.
Care & Protection of Lillith, 61 Mass. A.relevant_excerpt: “Parental unfitness must be determined by taking into consideration a parent’s character, temperament, conduct, mental stability, home environment, and capacity to provide for the child in the same context with the child’s particular needs, affections and age.” Adoption of Mary, 414 Mass. 705, 711 (1993). … The judge found that the father was able “to provide [the child] with a stable and nurturing environment in which to grow” once the child was placed with him…

Petelinsek v. Turner, 92 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Petelinsek v. Turner, 92 Mass. App. Ct. 618, 621–22 (2018)
Petelinsek v. Turner, 92 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Where a material change has occurred that may adversely affect the children’s safety, the Court is not required to wait until more serious harm occurs before acting; it may adopt reasonable, protective conditions to prevent further risk. See Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. at 225–26; Petelinsek v. Turner, 92 Mass. App. Ct. 618, 621–22 (2018).
Petelinsek v. Turner, 92 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal case about cross-examination by innuendo, expert testimony, and voluntariness of statements/Miranda waiver in a firearms prosecution. It does not involve child custody, material changes affecting children’s safety, or the court’s ability to impose protective conditions to prevent future harm. The proposition concerns child-welfare style protective action, which is not discussed anywhere in Petelinsek v. Turner, so the case does not support that proposition.
Petelinsek v. Turner, 92 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: The provided text contains no discussion of child custody, children’s safety, material changes in circumstances, or the adoption of protective conditions. It focuses exclusively on evidentiary rules for cross-examination, expert testimony, and the voluntariness of the defendant’s statements in a firearms case.
